claims.claim: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination enhances the diversity of antigens presented on tumor cells.

evidence.quote: Fraction of tumor proteins represented in immunopeptidome | 62.3% | 37.3%
Fraction of proteins represented in MHC-I peptidome | 40.6% | 20.6%

claims.caveat: The effect is demonstrated in mouse models and the breadth of applicability to human tumors is not fully established.

claims.claim: mRNA vaccination in tumors induces a type I interferon response, a key step in immune activation.

evidence.quote: Type I interferon response score (normalized units) | 3.1 | 1.0
Intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers local innate sensing and type I interferon signaling.

claims.caveat: The magnitude of the interferon response may vary between different tumor types and microenvironments.

claims.claim: The combination of intratumoral mRNA vaccination and anti-PD-L1 therapy improves tumor control in preclinical models.

evidence.quote: Combined intervention improves tumor control in mice and aligns with better outcomes in the retrospective human cohort.

claims.caveat: These are preclinical results in mice, and may not directly translate to human clinical outcomes.

claims.claim: Prior mRNA vaccination is associated with improved survival in metastatic patients treated with ICIs.

evidence.quote: Retrospective human survival comparison p-value | p=0.01 | N/A
The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; residual confounding is likely.

claims.caveat: This is a retrospective, non-randomized analysis, so the association may be due to confounding variables rather than a causal effect of the vaccine.
